Oh all ye Britain Powers! Oh great Andate,
Pity my Youth! Oh Mercy! Mercy! Mercy!

div.stage: Appear Bonduca, Claudia, Nennius and Bonvica above.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Now Claudia, now Bonvica, O my Children!
Is the time come to ſhew your conſtant Valours?
Think not, my Girls, we will be Slaves to Rome;
No, we will ſhew theſe Lords o'th' World, theſe Romans,
How they ſhou'd die with Honour: Hark!
They come, ſince we muſt fall, fall bravely.

div.stage: Enter Suetonius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius, Curius and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Bring up the Catapults, and ſhake the Walls;
We will not be out-brav'd thus.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Shake the Earth;
You cannot ſhake our Souls: Bring up your Rams,
And with their Armed Heads make the Fort totter.
You do but rock us into Death.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Yield Noble Queen.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I'm unacquainted with that Language, Romans.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Yield Honour'd Lady, and expect our Mercy;
We love thy Nobleneſs.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I thank ye, you ſay well,
But Mercy and Love, are ſins in Rome and Hell.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: You cannot ſcape our Strength, you muſt
Yield, Lady, you muſt adore, and fear the Power of Rome.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: If Rome be Earthly, why ſhou'd any Knee
With Bending Adoration Worſhip her?
She's Vicious, and your partial ſelves confeſs,
Aſpires the height of all Impiety;
Therefore 'tis fitter I ſhou'd Reverence
The Thatcht Houſes where the Britains dwell
In careleſs Mirth; where the beſt Houſhold Gods
See nought but chaſte and ſimple Purity,
'Tis not high Pow'r that makes a place Divine;
But ſacred Thoughts in holy Boſoms ſtor'd,
Make People Noble and the place Ador'd.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Beat the Wall deeper.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Beat it to the Center,
We will not ſink one Thought.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O Mother! Theſe are fearful Hours: Speak gently
To theſe fierce Men, they will afford us pity.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Pity thou fearful Girl? 'Tis for thoſe Wretches
That Miſery makes tame: Would'ſt thou live leſs?
Waſt thou not Born a Princeſs? Can my Blood
And thy brave Father's Spirit, ſuffer in thee
So baſe a Separation from thy ſelf,
As Mercy from theſe Tyrants?
Say they had Mercy.
The Devil! A Releuting Conſcience!
The Lives of Kings reſt in their Diadems,
Which to their Bodies, lively Souls do give,
And ceaſing to be Kings, they ceaſe to Live.

sp.speaker: Decius.
sp.l: There's a Breach made, is it your Will
We Charge, Sir?

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Once more Mercy, Mercy to all that yield.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Hear me, mark me well, and look upon me
Directly in my Face, my Womans Face,
Whoſe only Beauty, is the hate it bears you.
See with thy narroweſt Eyes, thy ſharpeſt Wiſhes
Into my Soul, and ſee what there inhabits;
See if one fear, one ſhadow of a terrour,
One paleneſs dare appear, but from my Anger,
To lay hold on your Mercies. No, ye Fools,
Poor Fortune's Fools, we were not born for Triumphs
To follow your gay ſports, and fill your Slaves
With • oo • s and • cc • amations.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Brave Behaviour!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The Children of as great as Rome; as Noble
Our Names before her, and her Deeds our Envy;
Muſt we gild o're your Conqueſt, make your State
That is not fairly ſtrong but fortunate.
No, no, ye Romans, we have ways to ſcape you
To make you poor again, indeed our Priſoners,
And ſtick our Triumphs full.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: D'ye wonder we'll make our Monuments
In ſpight of Fortune, in ſpight of all
Your Eagles Wings? We'll work a pitch above ye.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Decius, go Charge the Breach.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Stick in thy Body, and make it good but half an hour.

sp.speaker: Nenn.
sp.l: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And then be ſure to Die.

sp.speaker: Nenn.
sp.l: It ſhall go hard elſe.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Farewel, brave Nennius, we ſhall meet yonder,
Where few of thoſe muſt come.
Bring up the Poiſon.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O my Fortune!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Hah! What ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: Good Mother, nothing to offend you.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Here, Girl: behold us, Romans.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Mercy yet.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: No Talking, come, ſhort Prayers, and let's diſpatch
The Buſineſs. You begin, ſhrink not.
I'll ſee you do't.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O Gentle Mother!
O Romans! O my Heart! I dare not.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Woman! Woman! Unnatural Woman!

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! perſwade her Romans: Alas I am Young,
And wou'd Live, Noble Mother. Can you kill
That you gave Life to? Are my Years
Fit for Deſtruction?

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Yield, and be a Queen ſtill, a Mother and a Friend.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ye talk in vain, come Drink it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Fie, Siſter, fie! What wou'd you live to be?

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: Mercy. O Mercy!

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Hear her, thou wretched Woman.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: Mercy, Mother! O whither will ye ſend me?
I was once your Darling. Your Delight.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: O Gods! Fear in my Family? Do it, and Nobly.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! Do not frown then.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Do it, Worthy Siſter.
'Tis nothing; 'tis but a Pleaſure; we'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! If I knew but whither!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: To the Bleſs'd above, where we ſhall meet our Father,
Where nothing but true Joy is.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: O! Comfort me ſtill for Heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: No Wars, no Luſtful Slaves to Raviſh us.

sp.speaker: Bonv.
sp.l: That ſteals me along; farewel to this World.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: That's my Good Girl.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The next is mine.
Show me a Roman Lady in all your Stories
Dare do this for her Honour?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Make haſte.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I will. Wou'd you learn how to Die bravely, Romans;
To fling off this Caſe of Fleſh, loſe all your Cares
For ever, hunt Honour and not Nations with your Sword:
Keep your Minds humble, your Devotions high,
So ſhall you learn the Nobleſt part, to Die.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I come, my Noble Children, here,
Here's the Draught wou'd ask no leſs than Caeſar's ſelf
To pledge it for the Glories ſake.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Madam, make up your own Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: So we will.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Stay, be any thing.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: A Saint, Suetonius, when thou ſhalt fear and Die
Like a Slave; ye Fools, you ſhou'd have ty'd
Up Death firſt when ye Conquered.
You ſweat for us in vain elſe, ſee him here,
He's ours ſtill, and our Friend Laughs at your Pities;
And we command him with as eaſie Reins
As do our Enemies. I feel the Poiſon.
Poor Vanquiſht Romans, with what matchleſs
Tortures cou'd I now Rack you, but I pity ye,
Deſiring to Die quiet; nay, ſo much
I hate to proſecute my Victory,
That I will give you Counſel e're I Die,
If you will keep your Laws and Empire whole,
Place in your Romans Fleſh, a Britiſh Soul.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Deſperate and Strange!
Give her fair Funeral, ſhe was Noble, and a Queen.
Petilius haſte, draw out three Companies,
And make up inſtantly to Caratach.
What means this Ceremony?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The Body of Young Junius, that was
Slain in the laſt Battle.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Go then Petilius, do as I commanded.
After due Ceremony done to th' Dead,
The Noble Dead, we'll follow you.

div.stage: Enter Caratach upon a Rock, and Hengo by him Sleeping.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Thus we Afflicted Britains climb for Safeties,
And to avoid our Dangers ſeek Deſtructions.
Thus we awake to Sorrows, O thou Woman!
Thou Agent for Adverſities! What Curſes
This Day belong to thy Improvidence?
To Britans, by thy means? What ſad Millions
Of Widows weeping Eyes? The Strong Man's Valour
Thou haſt betray'd to Fury; the Childs Fortune
To fear and want of Friends, whoſe Pieties
Might wipe his Mournings off, and build his Sorrows
A Houſe of Reſt by his Bleſt Anceſtors.
The Virgins thou haſt robb'd of all their Wiſhes,
Blaſted their blowing hopes, turn'd their Songs,
Their Mirthful Marriage Songs, to Funerals,
The Land thou haſt left a Wilderneſs of Wretches.
The Boy begins to ſtir, thy ſafety made,
Wou'd my Soul were in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O Noble Uncle! Look out, I dreamt we were betray'd.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: No harm Boy, 'tis but thy Emptineſs, that breeds
Theſe Fancies, thou ſha't have Meat anon.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: A little, Uncle, and I ſhall hold out bravely.

div.stage: Enter Macer and Soldiers with Meat and a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Hang it o'th' ſide o'th' Rock, as tho' the Britains
Stole hither to Relieve him: who firſt ventures
To fetch it off is ours; I cannot ſee him,
He lies cloſe in a hole above, I know it,
Gnawing upon his Anger: Ha! No, 'tis not he.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis but the ſhaking of the Boughs.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Plague ſhake 'em, I'm ſure they ſhake me ſoundly.
There.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Make no noiſe, if he ſtir, a deadly Tempeſt
Of huge Stones fall upon us: 'Tis done, cloſe, cloſe.

sp.speaker: Cara
sp.l: Sleep ſtill, ſleep ſweetly Child, 'tis all thou feed'ſt on;
No Gentle Britain near, no Valiant Charity
To bring thee Food; poor K 〈…〉 thou art Sick,
Extream Sick, almoſt grown wild for Meat,
And yet thy Goodneſs will not confeſs, nor ſhow it;
All the Woods are double loin'd with Soldiers,
No way left us to make a Noble Eſcape;
I'll ſi • down by thee, and when thou wak'ſt,
Either get Meat to ſave thee, or loſe my Life
I'th' Purchaſe: Good Gods comfort thee, Ha!
Courage my Boy, I have found Meat; look Hengo,
Where ſome Bleſſed Britain to preſerve thee,
Has hung a little Food and Drink: Chear up Boy,
Do not for ſake me now.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O Uncle! Uncle! I feel I cannot ſtay long,
Yet I'll fetch it to keep your Noble Life.
Uncle I am heart-whole, and wou'd live.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Thou ſha't long, I hope.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: But my Head, Uncle!
Methinks the Rock goes round.
Don't you hear the noiſe of Bells?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Of Bells Boy! 'Tis thy fancy,
Alas, thy Body's full of Wind.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Methinks, Sir, they ring a ſtrange ſad Knell,
A Preparation to ſome near Funeral of State.
Nay, weep not, my own ſweet Uncle,
You will kill me ſooner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O my poor Chicken!

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Fie, faint-hearted Uncle!
Come tie me in your Belt, and let me down.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll go my ſelf, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: No, as you love me, Uncle.
I will not eat if I do not fetch it,
The danger only I deſire, pray tie me.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: I will, and all my Care hang over thee;
Come Child, my Valiant Child.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Let me down apace, Uncle,
And you ſhall ſee how like a Daw I'll whip it
From all their Policies; for 'tis moſt certain
A Roman Train, and you muſt hold me ſure too,
You'll ſpoil all elſe; when I have got it Uncle,
We'll be as merry—

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Go i'th' Name of Heaven, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Quick, quick Uncle, I have it. Oh!

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: What ail'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O my beſt Uncle, I am ſlain!

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: I ſee ye, and Heaven direct my Hand.
Deſtruction go with thy Coward Soul.
How do'ſt thou Boy? O Villain! Villain! Villain!

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O Uncle, Uncle! How it pricks me!
Am I preſerv'd for this? Extreamly pricks me.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Coward, Raſcal, Coward, Dogs eat thy Fleſh.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O! I bleed hard, I faint too upon't.
How ſick I am; the Lean Rogue, Uncle—

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Look Boy, I have laid him ſure enough.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Have ye knockt his Brains out?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: I warrant thee, from ſtirring more;
Chear up Child.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Hold my Sides hard, ſtop, ſtop, O wretched Fortune!
Muſt we part thus? Still I grow ſicker, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Heaven look upon this Noble Child!

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I once hoped
I ſhou'd have liv'd to have met theſe bloody Romans
At my Swords point, to have Reveng'd my Father's,
To have beaten 'em. O hold me hard Uncle—

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Thou ſha't live ſtill I hope, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I wou'd live a little longer;
Spare me Heavens, but only to thank you
For your tender Love. Good Uncle,
Good Noble Uncle weep not.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: O my Chicken! My Dear Boy! What ſhall I looſe—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why a Child that muſt have Dy'd however,
Had this eſcaped me, Feaver, or Famine:
I was Born to Die, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: But thus unblown, my Boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I ſhall go the ſtreighter my Journey to the Gods:
Sure I ſhall know when you come, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Yes, Boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And I hope we ſhall enjoy together
That Great Bleſſedneſs you told me of?

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Moſt certain, Child.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I grow Cold, my Eyes are going.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Lift 'em up.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Pray for me, and, Noble Uncle, when my
Bones are Aſhes, think of your little Nephew. Mercy.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Mercy, you Bleſſed Angels take him.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Kiſs me, ſo farewel, farewel.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Farewel the Hopes of Britain,
Thou Royal Graft, farewel, farewel:
Time, and Death, you have done your worſt.
Fortune, now ſee, now proudly pluck off this Veil
And view thy Triumph: Look, look
What thou haſt brought this Land to;
O Fair Flower! How lovely yet thy Ruins ſhow!
How ſweetly, even Death embraces thee.
The Peace of Heav'n; the Followſhip of all.
Great Souls be with thee.

div.stage: Enter Suetonius, Petilius, with Roman Soldiers,

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Yield thee, bold Caratach; by all the Gods, I ſwear,
As I'm a Soldier, as I envy thee,
I'll uſe thee like thy ſelf, th' Valliant Britain.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Brave Soldier, yield:
Thou Stock of Arms and Honour!
Thou filler of the World with Fame and Glory!

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Excellent Britain, do me but that honour;
That more to me than Conqueſt, that true happineſs
To be my Friend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O Romans! See what here is! 〈…〉 Boy liv'd!—

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: For Fame's ſake, forthy Sw 〈…〉
As thou deſir'ſt to build thy Virtues 〈…〉 —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No Roman! No! I wear 〈…〉 Soul:
A Soul too great for Slav'ry.— 〈…〉 Boy!
My dear lov'd Hengo! From thy 〈…〉 down!
Behold the laſt of thy great Race 〈…〉 ing!
Suetonius, view this little Cas 〈…〉 ,
By Roman Rapine Robb'd of all his Wealth.
A fair rich Soyl; that Precious Royal Gem,
By Fate's too Barbarous Hand, untimely ſnatcht!
Theſe Tears. I ſacrifice to thee, my Boy!
But to my Queen, and my unhappy Country,
This richer Purple Stream, my Blood I give.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: O thou too envy'd Miracles of Worth!
What baſt thou done? Nas Rome, too poor a Miſtreſs,
To Wed thee to her Arms? Not one Charm
In all her Courting Smiles, and Proffer'd Lawrels?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Rome, Sir. ah, no! She bids a Price too ſmall,
To Bribe me into Life: my bleeding Country
Calls me to Nobler. Wreaths; and in her Fall,
To mount a Star in Albion's long, long Night:
And when her Caratach dies in ſuch a Cauſe,
A Britiſh Tomb, outſhines a Roman Triumph.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: Prodigious Virtue!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Out-live my Country's Liberty!
Shall Caratach dare but to think that Thought!
Now Britain is all yours; but as my Blood,
From this ſmall Fountain flows, grant me one Favour:
Lay this Young Britiſh Roſe, Cropt in the Bud,
Cloſe by my ſide; and ſince the World▪ your own,
Spare us but Earth enough to cover o'er
Theſe ſmall Remains, and I ſhall ask no more.

sp.speaker: Suet.
sp.l: That Hollow'd Relick! Thou Rich Diamond!
Cut with the own Duſt! Thou, for whoſe wide Fame,
The would appears too narrow all Man's thought,
Had they all Tongues too ſilent! Thus I bow
To thy moſt Honoured Aſhes, tho' an Enemy,
Yet Friend to all thy Worths: Sleep peaceably.
Happineſs Crown thy Soul, and in thy Earth
Some▪ Lawrel fix his Seat; there grow and Flouriſh:
And make thy Grave an Everlaſting Triumph
Farewel all Glorious Wars, now thou art gone.
All Noble Battels!
Maintain'd in Thirſ 〈…〉 and not of Blood.
Farewel for ever. No 〈…〉 pleaſe,
Bear off the Noble 〈…〉 a File
High as Olimpus, that may 〈…〉 wonder,
To ſee a Star on Earth, o 〈…〉
O ever Lov'd, and ever L 〈…〉
Thy Honour'd, and moſt 〈…〉 Memory!

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.byline: Spoken by Miſs. DENNY CHOCK, But Six Years Old.

lg.l: WELL, now to ſpeak a Good Word for the Play,
Dear Gallants, but alaſs, What can I ſay?
I am too Young for your kind Smiles to pray.
When we ask Favours, Naughty Men, from you,
We muſt be Old enough to grant 'em too.
Old! Pray how Old! O Yes, our Cupid's Darts
Must first be Feather'd, e're we ſhoot at Hearts;
But theſe weak Eyes, too feeble Charms; 'tis true,
You may look Babies there, but that won't do;
We muſt be able to make Babies too.
Who knows what Charms I have? I hear
A Gentle Story whiſper'd in your Ear,
Has that ſtrange power, nay, Sirs, if that will get ye,
You'll find that I can prattle very pretty,
You heard me t'other Day in Young Queen Betty.
Such Honey-words, ſuch dear ſoft words I'll call,
Say ſuch fine things, if ſaying will do all:
Ah no, the ſoft white Birds that ſing to you,
Muſt be grown up to Bill as well as Cooe,
And I'm too ſmall to win your Hearts that way,
But tho' I'm yet too Young for Turtles play,
By your warm Suns a Blooming Flower I'll grow,
And keep my Roſe-bud, for your Smiles to Blow.

div.head:
A Catalogue of ſome Plays Printed for
〈◊〉 . 〈…〉 tley in Ruſſel-ſtreet in Covent Garden.

Mr. Nathaniel Lee's Plays: In one Volume.
Mr. Otway's Plays: In one Volume.
Mr. Shadwel's Plays: In one Volume.
Mr. Dryden's Plays: In two Volumes.
His other Poems: One Volume more.

4 Ambitious Stateſman, or the Loyal Favourite.
11 All for Love, or the World well loſt.
13 Aſſignation, or Love in a Nunnery.

list.head: B.

list.head: C.

20 Chances, a Comedy, altered by the Duke of Buckingham.

list.head: D.

33 Deſtruction of Jeruſalem, in two Parts.

list.head: E.

41 Eſſex and Elizabeth, or the Unhappy Favourite.

list.head: F.

45 The Fond Husband, or, Plotting Siſters.

52 Gloriana, or the Court of Auguſtus Caeſar.
